awd_titl_txt: CICI: SSC: SciTrust: Enhancing Security for Modern Software Programming Cyberinfrastructure
awd_abstract_narration:
Software plays a vital role supporting scientific communities. Modern software programming cyberinfrastructure (CI), consisting of online discussion platforms (such as Stack Overflow) and social coding repositories (such as Github), offers an open-source and collaborative environment for distributed scientific communities to expedite the process of software development. Within the ecosystem, researchers and developers can reuse code snippets and libraries, or adapt existing ready-to-use software to solve their own problems. Despite the apparent benefits of this new social coding paradigm, its potential security-related risks have been largely overlooked; insecure or malicious codes could be easily embedded and distributed, which could severely damage the scientific credibility of CI. Therefore, there is an urgent need for developing scalable techniques and tools to automatically detect these open-source insecure or malicious codes. To address this issue, this proposed project seeks to explore innovative links between Artificial Intelligence (AI) and cybersecurity to enhance the security of modern software programming CI. 

The key components of the proposed research are three-fold: (1) a novel AI-based solution (iTrustSO) utilizing social coding properties is developed to automatically identify suspicious insecure code snippets on Stack Overflow; (2)  a cross-platform model is constructed to represent the complex interplay between GitHub and Stack Overflow; deep learning techniques are then utilized to build a predictive model (iTrustGH) for automatic detection of malicious codes on GitHub; and (3) a user-friendly tool (SciTrust) is developed to enhance code security for software development. The broader impacts of this work include benefits to scientific communities and the whole society by promoting the efficiency of cyber-enabled software development without sacrificing the security. The establishment of a Cybersecurity Lab through this project enhances the education and workforce training in cybersecurity. The project integrates research with education through curriculum development and student mentoring activities for the newly-established cybersecurity degree program. It is also expected to increase the participation of underrepresented groups including minority and women.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the broad scale proliferation of connected devices and systems, software running on these interconnected devices and systems have played a vital role supporting scientific communities. Modern software programming cyberinfrastructure (CI), consisting of online discussion platforms (e.g., Stack Overflow) and social coding repositories (e.g., GitHub), offers an open-source and collaborative environment for distributed scientific communities to expedite the process of software development. Within the ecosystem, researchers and developers can reuse code snippets and libraries, or adapt existing ready-to-use software to solve their own problems. Despite the apparent benefits of this new social coding paradigm, its potential security-related risks have been largely overlooked - i.e., insecure or malicious codes or repositories could be easily embedded and distributed, which could severely damage the scientific credibility of CI. In particular, malicious code/software has been used as a major weapon by cyber threat actors to compromise security of CI - e.g., the global cost of ransomware attacks is expected to exceed $30 billion in 2023. To address this issue, this project aims to develop innovative links between Artificial Intelligence (AI) and cybersecurity to enhance the security of modern software programming CI. With the support of this grant, during the project period, the team has had 68 publications (including 2 Ph.D. dissertations and 1 MS thesis) in recognized journals (e.g., TMLR, IEEE TKDE, ACM CSUR) and in proceedings of highly competitive conferences with acceptance rate about or less than 20% (e.g., ECIR'2023, EMNLP'2022, NeurIPS'2021-2022, IJCAI'2019-2022, CIKM'2019-2022, SGIKDD'2020-2022, ICSE'2022, USENIX Security'2022, ACSAC'2019-2020, etc.). The research outcomes have been widely disseminated to research communities and practitioners through the publications, presentations, seminars, project website and demos, media presses, etc. Specially, with partial support of this project, the PI and her team have received the AAAI-DCAA 2023 Best Paper Runner-Up Award, the SIGKDD 2022 Best Paper Award Shortlist (Research Track), the prestigious ACM CIKM 2021 Best Paper Award (Full Paper Track), and the ACM CIKM 2021 Best Paper Runner-Up Award (Applied Paper Track), and the AAAI-AICS 2019 Challenge Problem Winner.

The proposed techniques and developed systems in this project have benefited scientific communities and society by promoting the efficiency of cyber-enabled software development without sacrificing the security. The research tasks in this project also offer an opportunity for researchers and scientific communities to be proactive against cybersecurity threats especially when they are involved with important CI. In addition, the research work is also beneficial to the AI and data science communities when large-scale, multi-source, multi-modal data is involved. The outcomes of this project (including open-source code and benchmark) have been made publicly accessible; and broadly distributed through publications, presentations, seminars, demonstrations, etc. The project has integrated research with education through curriculum development, K-12 outreach activities and engaging graduate and undergraduate students in research (e.g., one postdoc, four Ph.D. students and one master student have been recruited). The project has also increased the involvement of underrepresented groups, including minority and women (e.g., three female graduate students have involved in working on AI and data driven research related to this project).

Modified by: Yanfang Ye
